title: House GOP clashes over plan to avoid government shutdown
content:
House Speaker Paul Ryan of Wis. walks to a news conference on Capitol Hill in Washington , Wednesday , Sept. 7 , following a meeting with House Republicans . | AP Photo House GOP clashes over plan to avoid government shutdown
House Republicans took a first awkward step toward avoiding a government shutdown Friday , as hardline conservatives clashed with Speaker Paul Ryan behind closed doors even as something close to a consensus began to emerge .
A small group of conservatives pushed Ryan during a House GOP Conference meeting to back a long-term spending bill that funds the government at current levels into spring 2017 . But most of the Republicans who stood up to speak appeared to support a short-term stopgap that runs to mid-December , according to sources in the room . That position — already embraced by the Senate GOP , congressional Democrats and the White House — would buy lawmakers more time to negotiate a larger spending deal for all of fiscal 2017 .
The at-times contentious conference meeting comes just weeks before the government runs out of money on Sept. 30 . Republican leaders are adamant that they will not allow the government to shut down in what 's proving to be a tough election year for the GOP with Donald Trump at the top of the ticket .
Still , Ryan and his top lieutenants , Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy ( R-Calif. ) , Whip Steve Scalice ( R-La . ) and Conference Chair Cathy McMorris Rodgers ( R-Wash. ) , are seeking a path that will garner the support of a majority of his GOP conference . And Friday morning ’ s meeting showed they still have some work to do .
Ryan opened up the session by going through the pros and cons of both a three-month and six-month continuing resolution . He also floated the idea of passing `` mini-bus '' spending packages , clustering two or three agency funding bills together at once , rather than a massive omnibus that combines 12 bills to fund the government .
“ There ’ s a realization within the conference that an omnibus is not popular , ” House Appropriations Chairman Hal Rogers ( R-Ky. ) told reporters after the meeting . “ The idea is to try to do a few mini-buses that are bite-sized appropriations that we can digest and look at carefully . ”
Many lawmakers exiting the meeting liked the pitch , though the conference was not completely unified .
`` Some people are for a short-term , some people are for a long term , '' said Rep. Tim Murphy ( R-Pa. ) , who noted he personally liked the mid-December plan .
`` There is nothing good that is going to come out of a funding bill in the lame duck session , '' said conservative Rep. Louis Gohmert ( R-Texas ) , echoing concerns held by the House Freedom Caucus . They fear leadership will negotiate an expensive $ 1 trillion year-end spending package favorable to Democrats . That 's the principle reason conservatives say they want to punt into next year .
Rep. Markwayne Mullin ( R-Okla. ) said he personally liked the idea and felt that mini-buses would make a short-term CR more palatable to conservatives or others on the fence .
`` I like it . When we start talking about doing a large spending bill it causes problems and is hard for people to understand , '' he said . `` When we break it down ... it 's easier for people to wrap their head around . ''
But not everyone was so receptive . Freedom Caucus Chairman Jim Jordan , sources in the room said , stood up to argue the case against a short-term CR and said Senate Minority Leader Harry Reid ( D-Nev. ) would never allow mini-buses to pass . Rep. Scott Garrett likewise got into a back-and-forth with Ryan over what he called Reid 's failure to reasonably negotiate with the House — and the unlikelihood that they could get him on board with Ryan 's mini-bus preference .
Several Republicans also suggested trying to attach conservative-favored provisions to a CR , such as halting the resettlement of Syrian refugees into the United States and blocking the Obama administration from relinquishing authority over internet oversight , said Republican Study Committee Chairman Bill Flores ( R-Texas ) . The House Freedom Caucus floated the idea during a Tuesday huddle with conservatives .
“ If we still are a conservative House and we still have a majority here , express our will and those are things we want , ” Flores said .
But even such policy riders might not be enough to sway skeptical conservatives . Rep. Dave Brat ( R-Va. ) said he would still oppose a short-term CR with such sweeteners .
Still , of about 50 members that spoke during the closed-door meeting , most favored a three-month bill . Supporters argued that Republicans should be `` smart '' this fall and avoid even the hint of a government shutdown before the election .
Defense hawks were some of their strongest allies in the room .
“ My view is CRs always damage defense and the longer they are , the more damage they do ” said House Armed Services Chairman Mac Thornberry ( R-Texas . )
Many Republicans are also bullish that money to combat the Zika virus will be attached to a CR this month .
`` I 'm confident that we 'll be able to get it done in the next few weeks , '' said Rep. Mario Diaz-Balart , a senior GOP appropriator from Florida , where the mosquito-borne virus is spreading quickly .
Senate Republicans appear increasingly willing to allow Planned Parenthood clinics to receive Zika response funding — which Democrats had demanded during repeated filibusters of a House-passed $ 1.1 billion measure .
House GOP leaders have so far been unwilling to go along , but Rep. David Jolly , another Florida Republican , said he expected a clean Zika package would ultimately be attached to the CR , in a win for Democrats .
`` Look it 's clear there 's not votes for any other path forward , '' he said . `` At the end of the day , it 's not rocket science what 's going to happen here . ''
Jolly added that the broader skirmish over government funding is “ almost anti-climactic , ” because even if conservatives balk at the short-term CR , enough House Republicans would join Democrats to keep the government funded , as has happened during previous fiscal fights . “ This is déjà vu all over again , ” he said . “ ” There ’ s almost little drama to it , because it ’ s so predictable what we ’ re going through right now . ”
